Award.AwardTitle: Spatial language and cognition beyond Mesoamerica

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How much spatial information is represented in language? To what extent do languages differ in the expression of geometrical and functional object structure? Is there variation in the role the human and animal body plays as a conceptual model of the structure of objects across languages? Do speakers of all languages employ the same conceptual processes in mapping the structure of the body into that of objects? Does the way the geometrical and functional structure of objects is conceptualized in different languages influence the way spatial relations are identified in these languages? And does the way speakers of different languages talk about spatial relations influence the way they memorize them? This project attempts to find answers to these and similar questions, based on an investigation of the representation of space in 25 languages spoken on five continents.

The overarching question is that of linguistic vs. nonlinguistic determinants of reference frame use in language and internal cognition. Previous research has confirmed the co-occurrence of a bias against relative (observer-projected) frames and the highly productive use of "meronymic" terminologies that are based primarily on object geometry across the languages of the Mesoamerican area. To test the hypothesis that shape-based meronymy, used as a resource in spatial descriptions, is in fact a causal influence in frame use, four non-Mesoamerican languages of South America, Africa, and Asia will be examined. Preliminary reports suggest the presence of Mesoamerican-style geometric meronymy in these languages. The alternative hypothesis, according to which frame selection is not directly driven by language, but exclusively by non-linguistic factors, will be tested in eight Asian populations. Among Mesoamerican languages, the team will further investigate an unexpected apparent side effect of the predominance of object-centered geometry: the "principle of canonical orientation", which prevents English speakers from saying "The ball is under the chair" when it is placed on top of an inverted chair, may be language-specific.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the oldest and most persistent questions in the history of science is that of nature vs. nurture, or the respective role of genetics and culture (the latter mediated by personal experience) in shaping the individual’s behavior.  Recent advances in the availability of affordable computational power have made it possible to subject large-scale crosslinguistic and cross-cultural data samples to sophisticated statistical analyses that can isolate the effects of language, culture, and the environment in spatial cognition.

The MesoSpace project has investigated for the first time how a single aspect of cognition – the use of ‘spatial reference frames’ – is shaped by language, literacy, education, age, gender, and two environmental variables, topography and population density. Reference frames are cognitive coordinate systems (technically axis systems) that serve to interpret both external (verbal) and internal (nonverbal) representations of space.

The project has examined the use of spatial reference frames in 13 populations speaking eight languages on three continents. For several of the languages (Bashkir (Turkic, Russia), Taiwanese Southern Min, Vietnamese), few or no published accounts of the use of reference frames had been available at the outset. There is evidence suggesting that the use of reference frames by the speakers of minority languages such as Bashkir is rapidly changing under the influence of dominant contact languages. MesoSpace has discovered new robust statistical evidence of language, formal education, literacy level, population density, and age playing a causal role in reference frame selection in both discourse and nonverbal cognition.

It has found new supporting evidence for the hypothesis of an innate pan-simian (or perhaps pan-mammalian) geocentrism bias (a bias for environment-anchored frames, as in 'The ball is north/uphill of the chair'), first proposed by Haun et al (2006) on the basis of experiments with human infants and adult non-human primates. In some modern human populations, this bias would be overridden by a culturally transmitted egocentrism bias (a bias for observer-anchored frames, as in 'The ball is in front of the chair' if the ball is located between chair and observer). Semantic typology can lend several new sources of support to this hypothesis: (i) Egocentrism bias has been attested solely in large-scale globalized post-industrial societies (speakers of Dutch, English, Japanese, Mandarin, Spanish). (ii) All attested populations in which intrinsic frame use (e.g., 'The ball is in front of the chair' if the ball the part of the chair closest to the ball is the front) dominates in discourse show evidence of a preference for geocentrism in nonlinguistic tasks. The data collected by MesoSpace member Nikitina from Bashkir (Turkic, Russia; Nikitina under revision) fits the pattern also evidenced by Kilivila (Oceanic, Papua New Guinea; Senft 2001), Mopan (Mayan, Belize; Danziger 2001), and Murrinhpatha (Southern Daly, Australia; Gaby et al under revision). (iii) The PI’s work on Yucatec Maya within the current project confirms several previous studies (Bohnemeyer 2011; Bohnemeyer & Stolz 2006; Le Guen 2011) all pointing to a mismatch between referential practices in discourse, where this population shows no clear preference for a particular frame type as a community, and nonverbal cognition, where geocentric solutions again dominate. (iv) MesoSpace I data from four Spanish-speaking communities of rural Mexico, Nicaragua, and Barcelona suggest that non-dominant geocentric use in discourse predicts dominant geocentric use in nonverbal cognition as long as the linguistic use is non-marginal (Bohnemeyer et al 2014). (v) This last-mentioned pattern was also found by MesoSpace member Lin in her dissertation research with bilingual speakers of Mandarin and Taiwanese Southern Min: these likewise matched non-marginal, but non-dominant geocentric use in the discourse task with dominant geocentric use in the recall memory task.

The MesoSpace team has also developed a scenario for the coevolution of manipulable space and egocentrism in modern humans. Geocentric frames afford more efficient representations of large-scale space, whereas egocentric frames afford representations that are more efficient for tasks associated with artifacts. Prime examples are the navigation of urban roadways and the use of conventional visual representations – especially writing – with their inherent egocentric viewpoint. As the importance of the control of artifacts and manipulable space has continuously grown in the course of cultural evolution, so has the “selectional pressure” promoting the adoption of egocentric frames. In this situation, speech, gesture, and other observable behaviors afford the intergenerational cultural transmission of egocentrism and its horizontal diffusion through contact. However, established cultural practices that involve geocentric usage (Bohnemeyer 2011) counteract the shift to egocentrism. Contact may in this situation become a catalyst. Support for the special role of small-scale space comes from the observation that cross-cultural variation is mostly restricted to this domain.
